comments.commentBody:
Today was NEATO. Because all those miners got back to the surface. (!)

Many answers I had not heard of before...MTA, SCOTTS (lawn care), MOSHE Arens and so on...so had to rely on crosses today, but I like how the theme was done. Thanks all!
cheers...

For me the top center went last, despite my owning three Alfas over the years, though never a Spider.  Great cars.  Lots of clever clues, good fill, all in all a fun puzzle.  TEC was new for me, but I suppose it comes from deTECtive.
I wondered if I was missing something.  Thanks, Joon!  That makes a lot more sense.

jim, there are actually seven theme answers, not three, and the key to noticing the extras is "and literally so." STAY is literally "between the lines" MASON-DIXON and WHITESTAR, and READ is between the FREE-THROW line and a PRODUCTION line. subtle, but i'd say that yes, it's just mind-bending enough for a thursday. :)

Thank you for the article, Dr. Tuttle.  I experienced some of the difficulties you described due to the uncertainty that can occur in determining whether a thyroid tumor is benign or malignant from the pathology.  When I was age 29, I had a thyroid lobectomy and isthmusectomy to remove a 4.5 cm follicular neoplasm.  The first pathologist who looked at it did not identify any capsular or vascular invasion or any necrosis, but did note some suspicious features including the presence of scattered mitoses, a predominantly solid/trabecular pattern of growth, and a high nucleocytoplasmic ratio.  He wasn't sure of the diagnosis and sent it to a more expert pathologist, who diagnosed it as "minimally invasive follicular thyroid carcinoma" on the basis of those features and also "pretty convincing evidence of capsular invasion as well as foci suggestive of vascular invasion".  My surgeon recommended completion thyroidectomy and one dose of radioiodine treatment, but also indicated that it would not be unreasonable for me to decide not to get any further treatment since I would have a low risk of recurrence.  Because I had read that the diagnosis of follicular thyroid carcinoma is usually made on the basis of definite invasion, and the opinions of the two pathologists seemed to differ on this point, I sought additional opinions from two more pathologists.  Neither of them reported definite invasion, but they did seem to err on the side of caution by deferring to the existing diagnosis.  Then I entered graduate school and got very busy, so I never finalized a decision about whether to get the further treatment that had been offered to me.  I am now 34, and have had no subsequent evidence of disease.  I get regular neck ultrasounds, and take Levoxyl to suppress my TSH as directed by my endocrinologist.  I still have the option of getting a completion thyroidectomy and radioiodine treatment.  Do have any thoughts on whether this case calls for such treatment given all the uncertainty in the pathology?

I solved the puzzle but, ummm, what is the theme?  I didn't think there was one, but since Jim says there is one, I guess he must be right.  Is it just STAY BETWEEN THE LINES and READ BETWEEN THE LINES?  Or are MASON-DIXON, WHITE STAR, PATINA, FREETHROW and PRODUCTION related somehow?

Wherever I travel I have a contact.  And I offer them my place to crash in NYC.  I have a friend of Mumbai whom I met over a wireless router problem.  He and his wife are welcome to backpack at my place.  I can't imagine thinking I've experienced a city/or country without personal contact.  My sister and I had a host in Helsinki who was the most magnificent "gentlemen" we have ever met.  The origin of these contacts are tenuous and can go back years but they are a most enriching aspect of life.
Landrieu is a craven DISGRACE to Democrats and Senators, and the Senate hold rule is a DISGRACE to democracy!
What a shameless oil industry puppet.  Hope she drowns in the next oil spill.
Get rid of the hold.  Vote out anyone who abuses it.

Senator Landrieu & Louisiana's political "class" help give us Katrina and the Gulf oil spill. By allowing, maintaining, rewarding (directly, indirectly, indifferently) un-safe environmental, infrastructural, safety & technology standards.

Nor does Sen. Landrieu speak an understanding the "highest" standards for safety & technology necessary "extraction" companies in Louisiana. Or the lack thereof & impact: commerce, environment, food-chain, human life, infrastructure and wild life.
I wondered if I was missing something.  Thanks, Joon!  That makes a lot more sense.

Dear Tea Party people,

I understand you are frustrated with Washington. Can't we agree you need to elect people who know something about what it's done, is doing, and can be done there in order to change it, if that's your goal?
If O'Donnell had referenced the "57 states" of the U.S., I guess that would have been her Obama moment?

here's a case she has disagreed with .:
the ‘Case’ that thinking Americans have made (and most of those in the GOP party) that she is SUPREMELY unqualified, in every way, to hold this office.

The fact that she is running despite what she knows to be her profound
deficit of experience, intelligence and particularly integrity, proves the point.

The "new normal" apparently includes an utter failure(on one side of the aisle) to expect would be Senators to have any grasp on stare decisis or follow the third branch in any meaningful way.

Monty Python helps to elucidate: "What makes you think she is a witch?"

"She turned me into a newt.... I got better..."

As Palin, Newt and O'donnell pretend that tax cuts for the rich will reduce deficits, the reality is they need to spend more time learning and less time bloviating. (or campaigning.......... next?)

BTW even witches know that Groucho was the best political Marxist, although Ms. O' Donnell has a Harpoesque vibe....

(do you think she actually has a clue what Marx wrote? She might post that on her website after Blossom's operatives clear it....)
O'Donnell, like Palin, is nothing more than a gumball machine of goofball quotes. Their combined IQ's would fall short of triple digits.

I think that the questioners at these debates should ask easier questions.

For example, next time around try: "Name a Supreme Court decision - any Supreme Court decision."

Paging Andy Warhol...paging Andy Warhol..."Miss O'Donnell, your fifteen minutes is...."

Oh heck--even I know that isn't true.

As Sarah Palin has demonstrated repeatedly, with the low info and know nothing crowd, being a blithering and totally uninformed idiot is no impediment to public office--heck--it appears to be a basic qualification.

Just watch.

If O'Donnell and her fellow nitwits win in November, we can look forward in 2012 to a Presidential candidate on the right who needs a drool cup.
"I'll put it up on my website". (so very lame)
I doubt that O'Donnell knows what the supreme court is. They didn't cover that one at Hogwart's.
No! It's the let's use this in the the New York times to Bash women moment!
Oy vey. Republicans, are either stupid, or willing to elect the stupid.

Christine was full of talking points and attacks on Coons. Coons focused on the issues and stayed away from personal attacks. Will this work for Coons?

Frankly, soundbites and slogans seem to be more popular this year than years of public service and policy knowledge. Christine should pick up some points in the polls, but her ignorance of any Supreme Court decision she opposed might have media legs.

I watched the debate on CNN, as an Independent voter I can assure you that O'Donnel won hands down.
Contrary to what the Times says, she did not stumble at all, on the contrary Mr. Coons
delivered himself of platitudes common to professional politicians. He is so experienced delivering his little thoughts that he brought out nothing of interest and if not O'Donnel's presence the audience was ready to nap.
Too bad that the discussion was interrupted by the rescue in Chile, heroic as the whole episode was, showing it over and over again was a bit too much.
